page.title: 07DALRY WILDLIFE
page.content: The situation in a valley, with many small rivers, is an asset in attracting a variety of wildlife. There are numerous common birds, like starlings, sparrows,thrushes, finches, and tits as well as dippers, herons and grebes and various types of duck. Birds are becoming fewer in number, and some, like the kingfisher,lapwing and corncrake, becoming rarer with the increasing use of weedkiller and pesticides and the removal of hedgerows. The marshy areas, like the "Duckie" near the station, are habitats for frogs, toads and newts as well as sedge warblers and reed buntings. They also harbour a variety of plant life, including mint, fennel, forget-me-nots and pink campion. There are only about three badgers left, and a few minks and otters.
